The nature and dynamics of poverty reduction efforts in Nepal, as well as its 
political economy, necessitate that the social inclusion and empowerment of 
disadvantaged groups (DAGs) be strengthened just as much as local bodies 
are. The rationale for this program also stems from the fact that the country 
will  soon  have  a  federal  form  of  government  in  which  subnational 
governments will play major roles in local development. Thus, strengthening 
local  governance  is  a  must.  Finally,  the  present  context  in  Nepal  demands 
reforms in local governance and community development  that are medium 
to long term, which justifies the program cluster approach of the GSP. 
 
The  GSP  is  in  line  with  the  Government’s  priorities  on  devolution  and 
subnational governance and contributes directly to desired outcomes in local 
governance and community development.  
 
The  proposed  program  cluster  for  supporting  local  governance  and 
community  development  in  Nepal  will  offer  phased  assistance  to  the

expected  impact  of  the  GSP  will  be  social  and  economic  transformation  in 
Nepal  through  (i)  capable  and  accountable  government  at  all  levels  that 
provides  effective  and  inclusive  services,  and  (ii)  empowered  communities 
that  engage  actively  with  government  to  hold  it  accountable.  ADB  will 
develop two subprograms to support the attainment of these outcomes. 
 
Subprogram  I  (SP1)  (2008–2012)  will  emphasize  community  mobilization 
and  strengthening  to  hold  local  bodies  accountable,  strengthening  their 
capability to provide effective and inclusive services and instituting relevant 
protocols  and  systems  in  the  central  Government  to  support  the  local 
governance  reform  agenda.  Subprogram 
II  (SP2)  (2012–2015)  will 
concentrate on the business process reengineering needed at the center to 
support a federal government structure, putting in place the legal framework 
for  proper  local  governance,  strengthening  the  fiscal  transfer  process  and 
system, and then strengthening community organizations and local bodies. 
 
 

 
SP1  will  support  the  Government’s  national  Local  Governance  and 
Community Development Program (LGCDP), which will contribute to poverty 
reduction  through  inclusive,  responsive,  and  accountable  local  governance 
and  participatory,  community-led  development.  There  are  three  main 
outcomes  that  SP1  will  contribute  to  through  its  support  to  the  LGCDP:  (i) 
citizens  and  communities  engage  actively  with  local  bodies  and  hold  them 
accountable; (ii) better management of resources and delivery of services in 
an  inclusive  and  equitable  manner  by  capable  local  bodies;  and  (iii) 
strengthened  policy  and  national  institutional  frameworks,  including  legal 
frameworks, for decentralization, devolution, and community development.

II. 

THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT1 

A. 

Economic Assessment and Outlook 

2. 
Between  2005  and  2007,  economic  growth  in  Nepal  averaged  only  2.8%  per  annum, 
well  short  of  even  the  pessimistic  scenario  of  the  tenth  plan,  which  had  targeted  4.3%.2 The 
growth of the gross domestic product (GDP) steadily slowed from 3.1% in fiscal year (FY) 2005 
to 2.8% in FY2006 and 2.5% in FY2007. In the current fiscal year, however, the economy grew 
at  5.6%,  propelled  by  strong  growth  in  agriculture  and  other  sectors.  This  is  the  fastest 
economic expansion in the past 7 years. The service sector, particularly tourism, has performed 
better than expected, but industrial growth has stagnated. The country’s per capita income now 
stands at $470. 
  
Fairly  sound  macroeconomic  policies  have  helped  preserve  macroeconomic  stability 
3. 
during  this  period.  With  the  resolution  of  the  internal  conflict,  the  Government  of  Nepal  (the 
Government) adopted an increasingly expansionary fiscal policy,3 but strong tax administration 
and  sustained  donor  assistance  were  sufficient  to  mitigate  the  adverse  effects  of  this  policy. 
Inflationary  pressures  exist  nevertheless.  While  the  rate  of  inflation  averaged  6.3%  during 
FY2005–FY2007,  by  mid-May  2008  it  had  reached  9.2%.  Still,  sustained  current  account 
surpluses  and  aid-related  capital  inflows  have  facilitated  continued  balance  of  payments 
surpluses.4 Remittance inflows have emerged as the major source of foreign exchange earnings, 
while merchandise exports have stagnated.  
 
4. 
Economic  growth  is  expected  to  be  around  4%  per  annum  in  the  coming  year,  but 
industrial  growth  is  likely  to  be  constrained  by  fuel  and  power  shortages,  continued  political 
uncertainty,  and  structural  weaknesses  in  the  economy.  Macroeconomic  stability  in  the  period 
ahead  will  depend  largely  on  a  continued  prudent  policy  stance,  particularly  in  addressing 
emerging  challenges  posed  by  new  fiscal  pressures  from  the  peace  process,  including  those 
related  to  Government  commitments  resulting  from  various  political  compromises;  higher  food 
and fuel prices; and chronic fuel and power shortages. 
 
B. 

Status of Spatial Poverty Reduction 

The Nepal Living Standards Survey in 2003/04 showed the poverty incidence declining 
5. 
sharply  from  42%  in  1996  to  31%  in  2004,  driven  by  growth  in  per  capita  consumption  and 
income,  each  averaging  4.5%  per  annum.  Nepal  may  have  made  progress  in  human

development,5 but the spatial incidence of poverty and depravation is a cause for rising concern. 
The country continues to have stark and widening socioeconomic disparities. The Nepal Living 
Standards Survey shows that income inequality increased significantly, with the Gini Coefficient 
rising  from  34.2%  in  1996  to  41.1%  in  2004.  Further,  the  11  percentage  point  drop  in  poverty 
was unevenly distributed geographically and across caste, ethnic, and minority groups. Poverty 
levels  are  still  high  in  rural  areas,  especially  in  the  Midwestern  region  (45%)  and  Farwestern 
region  (41%).  Poverty  is  much  worse  among  lower  caste  and  minority  groups,  such  as  Dalits, 
hill Janajatis, and Muslims (all above 40%), than in upper caste groups such as Brahmins and 
Chettris (19%) and Newars (14%). Gender disparities are stark, as women lag far behind men in 
all spheres of life despite efforts to improve equality.6  
 
6. 
This untenable situation has to be seen in the context of the political changes that have 
been  the  hallmark  of  Nepali  life  in  recent  years.  For  particular  political  parties,  the  economic 
straitjacket is juxtaposed with the need for dramatic and fundamental political reforms. Now that 
the country has moved from having a monarchy to being a federal democratic republic, and now 
that there is an elected government in place, a new economic model may well evolve that will 
seek to fundamentally realign the political economy of the country. 
 
7. 
The  main  tasks  facing  Nepal  at  present  are  (i)  formulating  a  new  constitution  that 
formalizes  the  recent  political  changes  in  the  country;  (ii)  restructuring  the  state,  including 
translating the vision of federalism into a more practical reality, while engendering public trust in 
government  and,  in  the  process,  giving  a  peace  dividend  to  the  people;  (iii)  reenergizing  the 
economy to capitalize on the more favorable political situation; and (iv) providing services in an 
inclusive manner so that the numerous disadvantaged groups (DAGs) can enter the economic 
and political mainstream of national life.

Since then, political governance has been characterized by attempts to steer the country 
toward a different political landscape. At the core of this is the consensus among political parties 
to  move  the  country  toward  a  federal  state  based  on  a  new  constitution  drafted  by  the 
Constituent Assembly, the elections for which were held in April 2008 after two postponements. 
 
10. 
The  Constituent  Assembly  elections  were  generally  peaceful  and  orderly,  with  a 
reasonably high voter turnout of 61%, reflecting the Nepali people’s aspiration for lasting peace 
and  stability.  In  what  came  as  a  surprise  to  many,  CPN(M)  won  the  largest  number  of  seats 
under both the first-past-the-post and the proportional representation electoral systems.9 In May 
2008,  the  Constituent  Assembly,  in  its  first  session,  formally  declared  Nepal  to  be  a  federal 
democratic  republic,  thus  ending  the  almost  two-and-half-century  reign  of  the  Shah  dynasty. 
The  Constituent  Assembly  itself  is  more  inclusive  of  historically  marginalized  groups  than 
previous legislatures,10 and this augurs well for the process of preparing the constitution.

Improving  Intergovernmental  Fiscal  Transfers  and  Funds  Flow.  To  make  local 
investments  more  responsive  to  community  needs,  the  Government  will  increase  the 
discretionary block grant that is currently transferred to local bodies. The defining feature of this 
expanded  block  grant  (EBG)  is  that  its  actual  allocation  is  never  an  entitlement  but  subject  to 
compliance  with  specified  minimum  eligibility  conditions  and  further  set  in  accordance  with  an 
annual  performance  assessment—a  minimum  conditions  and  performance  measures  (MCPM) 
system.20 The  actual  size  of  the  EBG  is  thus  adapted  to  proven  institutional  capacity  in  key 
functional  areas,  mainly  relating  to  public  financial  management,  and  so  provides  fiscal 
incentives  for  compliance  with  the  existing  legal  and  regulatory  framework  that  guides  the 
operations of local bodies. This makes the EBG and the MCPM system the first systematic and 
nationwide approach to promoting good governance and needs-based local service delivery.21 A 
second  salient  feature  of  the  EBG  is  that  its  basic  allocation  is  based  on  a  clear,  transparent, 
and  poverty-focused  formula.  This  positively  distinguishes  the  EBG  from  the  vast  majority  of 
conditional grants  that  flow  to  the  districts,  which  are  not  formula  based  and  thus  are  open  to 
unwarranted discretion in their allocation.

ADB  support  for  the  Government’s  reform  of  local  governance  and  community

where public awareness of rights in the political arena is at an all-time high, the program seeks 
to  ensure  that  these  rights  are  translated  into  opportunities  to  demand  and  attain  economic 
rights.  In  the  medium  term,  this  is  expected  to  make  local  good  governance  increasingly 
possible and emphasize inclusive development.

central  planning  and  operational  bodies;  (ii)  a  workable  interim  arrangement  on  local 
governance and community development until a federal structure of government is in place; and 
(iii) a contribution toward building urgently needed public trust in government. 
 

2. 

Social Benefits and Poverty Impact 

 
95. 
SP1  seeks  to  minimize  the  impact  of  vulnerabilities  to  poor  local  service  delivery.  The 
GESI  focus  of  the  program  particularly  will  target  better  access  for  women  in  DAGs  (see 
Appendix 11). In line with other relevant work of ADB on the gender theme, the GESI plan will 
be  implemented  as part  of  ADB  support  to  the  Government.  Dedicated  support to  the  work  of 
the LPCs in all districts where they operate now and in the future will mean that provisions will 
be  made  to  ensure  that  women  and  representatives  from  DAGs  have  an  opportunity  to 
participate  in  local  affairs.62 The  LPCs  are  central  to  applying  a  conflict-sensitive  approach  to 
local  development,  which  the  Government  and  development  partners  accept  as  the  primary 
means of bringing about inclusive development and public trust in local government.  
 
96. 
The  impacts  of  SP1  are  expected  to  be  evident  in  the  long  term  on  poverty  reduction.

society  gain  better  access  to  resources  and  opportunities.  This,  coupled  with  improvement  in 
the environment to provide feedback to local bodies, will mean that the socioeconomic benefits 
of the program will accrue to the poor as well. Greater scrutiny by communities will ensure that 
there  are  fewer  leakages  in  the  system,  thus  providing  more  resources  for  development 
activities.  Finally,  there  are  political  benefits  as  well,  as  SP1  will  enhance  transparency  and 
accountability  in  local  bodies  and,  hopefully,  bring  greater  public  trust  in  Government  in  the 
medium-to-long term. A summary social and poverty analysis is in Appendix 10.

105.  SP1 will have positive direct impact on socially disadvantaged groups, including women, 
indigenous  people,  and  ethnic  minorities  (Appendix  10).  The  implications  for  the  environment,

whereby officials of the district technical office and other relevant individuals will receive training 
on relevant skills to deal with long-term gaps. The necessary program assurance and budgeting 
provisions have been made in the program.

1. 

Structure 

2. 
The administrative divisions set up under the royal regime continue to be in place. In this 
set-up, there are 14 zones, which have ceased to be meaningful; 75 districts that are varied in 
terms of geographical characteristics and, more importantly, in terms of economic endowment; 
3,915 village development committees; and 58 municipalities. Development committees exist in 
all  districts  and  are  mandated  to  lead  development  work  in  the  local  governance  unit. 
Administrative  oversight  of  the  development  committees  is  provided  by  the  Ministry  of  Local 
Development  (MLD)  whose  mandate  is  to  involve  a  majority  of  the  people  in  the  decision-
making process of the governance system and empower them for overall development through 
local self-governance. 
 
The system of local governance consists of village development committees (VDCs) and 
3. 
municipalities  at  the  lower  level  and  district  development  committees  (DDCs)  at  the  upper.  All 
VDCs  are  divided  into  nine  wards,  and  there  are  several  community  settlements  in  each. 
Municipalities are divided into a minimum of nine wards and a maximum of 32. Wards are the 
smallest  units  of  local  governance.  Each  district  is  divided  into  nine  to  seventeen  Ilakas  (or 
areas), which cover clusters of VDCs and municipalities. Each district has a district council and 
an executive committee. The district council is made up of DDC chairpersons, vice-chairpersons 
and  members,  the  district’s  member(s)  of  Parliament,  mayors  and  deputy  mayors  of 
municipalities,  VDC  chairpersons  and  vice-chairpersons,  and  six  nominated  members.  The 
district council meets annually to discuss and approve DDC policies, programs, and budget. The 
district  executive  committee  runs  daily-to-day  DDC  affairs,  and  MLD  appoints  secretaries  in 
VDCs,  executive  officers  in  municipalities,  and  local  development  officers  in  DDCs.  It  also 
deputes  additional  professional  staff  such  as  accountants,  engineers,  and  planners  to  DDCs. 
Local  bodies  generally  appoint  lower-level  staff,  though  some  DDCs  have  started  to  appoint 
professional staff by themselves.

8. 
Social mobilization is central to managing and implementing the LGCDP. It is a key part of
